title: Here's where all the millennial millionaires live
text:
There are 618,000 'millennial millionaires' aged 23 to 37 in the U.S. and almost half of them are living in California, research has revealed.

And the population of wealthy young millennials, defined as people born between 1982 and 1996, is ever-increasing, according to a 2019 study from Coldwell Banker Global Luxury and WealthEngine.

Around 44% of millennial millionaires live in California, with the Golden State having the highest percentage of business owners (23%) and the highest percentage of real estate investors.

New York, (14%) Florida, (5%), Massachusetts, (5%), and Texas (5%) also have the highest proportion of millennial millionaires, the report found.

There are 618,000 'millennial millionaires' aged 23 to 37 in the U.S. and almost half of them are living in California, research has revealed

A study revealed that 44% of millennial millionaires live in California. New York had the second highest number of rich millennials, (14%), followed by Florida, Massachusetts, and Texas, (5%) in joint third place

The report notes that millennials prefer to live in densely populated cities and this is reflected in the Zip code areas that have the highest concentration of affluent young people.

Most of the top ZIP codes are primarily concentrated in Silicon Valley and the areas of Fremont, Cupertino, San Jose, Sunnyvale, Burlingame, Hillsborough and San Mateo.

The researchers say this reflects a 'strong tech connection' that is associated with their newfound wealth.

They also tend to prefer markets that are more affordable — often in suburbs or second-tier cities, where they will get more bang for their buck.

Karen Yang Coldwell Banker Residential Brokerage in Los Altos states: 'They want to live near gathering spaces.

'They want to live near throwback downtowns, or districts that grew organically — and they are willing to give up square footage and amenities to be able to live in those kinds of locations.

She added: 'They’re 26 years old, only a few years out of school, and they have just gotten a big equity play of $5 million because of what they can do at their desk behind a computer.

'They view real estate as a significant way to build wealth.'And millennials are projected to overtake baby boomers as the largest living adult generation in America.

By 2030, millennials will hold five times as much wealth as they have today, and are expected to inherit over $68 trillion from their predecessors in the Great Transfer of Wealth, the report finds.

The vast majority (93%) of millennial millionaires have a net worth between $1 million and $2.49 million. Most (about 45%) are between the ages of 34 and 37. About 15% of millennial millionaires are also business owners

The report notes that millennials prefer to live in densely populated cities and this is reflected in the Zip code areas that have the highest concentration of affluent young people

Baby boomer are those who were born between 1946 and 1964 and are regarded as are an economically influential generation. They are now reaching retirement age amid concerns over how they will fund their golden years.

The vast majority (93%) of millennial millionaires have a net worth between $1 million and $2.49 million.

Most (about 45%) are between the ages of 34 and 37. About 15% of millennial millionaires are business owners.

Despite California’s reign as the most popular state for millennial millionaires, another surprising destination for them was Traverse City, Michigan, which came out as the top living destination on the list of millennial zip-codes.

Set on the shores of Lake Michigan, Traverse City has historically been a tourist destination with a robust second-home market where luxury homes generally start at $500,000.

Millennial millionaires make up approximately 2% of the total U.S. millionaire population and 0.2% of the general U.S. population. This is roughly the same volume as the total millionaire population in the early 1980s

Millennials also now make up the largest group of home buyers in the nation. 92% of them of have purchased a property and the average real estate portfolio of millennial millionaires is worth $1,367,022, distributed across about three properties on average.

The prices are a far cry from many Silicon Valley ZIP codes, where luxury home prices generally start at about $2 million.

Traverse City has experienced an urban renaissance in the last 10 years, with a dynamic food scene, microbreweries, wineries and a vibrant arts and festival scene to attract younger generations of affluent homebuyers.

'The younger affluent like that they can get a fabulous home on, near or overlooking vineyards, fresh water or beaches for a fraction of the cost of larger metropolitan areas,' said Shawn Schmidt Smith, associate broker/owner for Traverse Citybased Coldwell Banker Schmidt.

'We have a full-service airport, making it easy to commute. We have strong schools. We’ve also become a foodie destination and a vibrant cultural community.'

When it comes to lifestyles and other interests, around 62% of millennial millionaires say that they are interested in health. A lot like to be located near yoga studios, fitness facilities and organic dining options.

Many millennials are actually foregoing car ownership completely, and depend on a combination of Lyft, Uber, public transportation and bike sharing.

The study also found that they are major consumers of digital information and technology.

Millennials are three times more likely to watch a video than Baby Boomers. Unsurprisingly they are the biggest users of social media platforms and manage everything from their financial to shopping needs online.
description: Almost half of young millionaires aged 23 to 37 are living in California and areas around Silicon Valley, suggesting they are working with tech companies.
